   land habitat / Groundnut crop field / faunal list] [Gujarat / Saurashtra
   Region / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI Syllidae (Polychaeta) from the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions.
AU Ramos, J.
   San Martin, G. (guillermo.sanmartin@uam.es) 
   Sikorski, A.
SO Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom
VL 90
IS 5
PS 1041-1050
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A collection of over one hundred specimens of Syllidae (Polychaeta) from
   the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions has been examined and identified. The
   specimens were obtained from 26 stations in the Barents Sea, some
   Norwegian fiords and localities of the northern North Sea. A total of 21
   species were identified; three species (Myrianida langerhansi (Gidholm,
   1967), Syllides long-ocirrata Orsted, 1845 and Sphaerosyllis taylori
   Perkins, 1981) are new reports for the Arctic Ocean; 2 species are new
   to science, Streptodonta exsulis sp. nov. and Trypanosyllis troll sp.
   nov. Streptodonta exsulis sp. nov. have 4 thick, distally strongly
   knobbed aciculae on each anterior parapodia, shifting to a single,
   slender acicula on posterior parapodia; falcigers and pseudospinigers
   distally bidentate; and pharyngeal tooth located centrally and
   relatively close to anterior rim of pharynx. Trypanosyllis troll sp.
   nov. have 2, occasionally 3 straight aciculae in parapodia protruding
   out from parapodial lobes; falcigers bidentate; and body surface densely
   covered by numerous, small papillae. Based on the description of these 2
   new species, some modifications are proposed in the diagnoses of the
   genera Streptodonta San Martin & Hutchings, 2006 and Trypanosyllis
   Claparede, 1864.
C1 San Martin, G.; Univ Autonoma Madrid, Fac Ciencias, Madrid, Spain,
   Spain.
EM guillermo.sanmartin@uam.es
SC Zoology
SN 0025-3154
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic

   [Arctic Ocean /  / New record]. 
   Streptodonta exsulis [North Atlantic /  / New species]. 
   Syllidae [Arctic Ocean / Barents Sea / Faunal list; systematics] [North
   Atlantic / Norway / ] [North Sea / North / ]. 
   Trypanosyllis troll [North Atlantic / Norway / New species].

   Syllidae (Polychaeta).

DT Article
TI Algal-dwelling Eophliantidae (Amphipoda): description of a new species
   and key to the world species, with notes on their biogeography.
AU Loerz, A.N. (a.loerz@niwa.co.nz) 
   Kilgallen, N.M.
   Thiel, M.
SO Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom
VL 90
IS 5
PS 1055-1063
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eophliantidae are poorly studied marine algal-dwelling amphipods with a
   wide distribution. A new species was found to excavate burrows across
   the main stem of Carpophyllum maschalocarpum (Turner) Grey, in the New
   Zealand subtidal, and a detailed morphological description of this
   amphipod is given. Bircenna macayai sp. nov. can be distinguished from
   other Bircenna species by a combination of the following characters:
   bibbed coxa 1, merus and carpus of pereopods 5 7 strongly extended
   posteriorly, crenulate basis of pereopod 7 and smooth posterior margin
   of epimeron 3, pereopod 7 basis longer than wide. A key to the fourteen
   world species of Eophliantidae is provided. Taxonomy, evolutionary
   sequences, functional morphology and biogeography of the Eophliantidae
   are briefly discussed. New Zealand and Australian shallow waters show
   the highest species diversity of Eophliantidae, containing both species
   bearing plesiomorphic and highly derived characters, suggesting that
   Australasia is an evolutionary centre for this amphipod family.
C1 Loerz, A.N.; Natl Inst Water & Atmospher Res, Wellington, New Zealand,
   New Zealand.
EM a.loerz@niwa.co.nz
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology

   Zoogeography; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   Eophliantidae [General morphology / Functional morphology / ]
   [Zoogeography / Worldwide distribution / ] [Marine zones /  / ].

   Peracarida, Amphipoda

TI Puntius rohani (Teleostei: Cyprinidae), a new species of barb in the
   Puntius filamentosus group from the southern Western Ghats of India.
AU Rema Devi, K. (remadevi_zsi@yahoo.com) 
   Indra, T.J.
   Knight, J.D. Marcus
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 2
IS 9
PS 1121-1129
PD August 2010
PY 2010
UR http://threatenedtaxa.org/index.asp?jid=54
AW http://threatenedtaxa.org/ZooPrintJournal/2010/August/o250526viii101121-
   1129.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Puntius rohani, a new species of cyprinid ish, is described from the
   Kanyakumari District, southern India. This species can be distinguished
   from the other members of the Puntius ilamentosus Group by the
   combination of the following characters: the absence of vertical black
   bands near the tips of the caudal in; the presence of an elongate black
   club-shaped blotch 1.5 scales high extending from the 12-13th
   lateral-line scales to the caudal-in base; and possessing 2-3+6-9 gill
   rakers on the irst gill arch, 21-23 lateral-line scales, seven predorsal
   scales, 1/2 4+1+3-3 1/2 scales in transverse line from the dorsal-in
   origin to the mid-ventral scale row, and 2-2 1/2 scales between the
   lateral line and the pelvic-in origin.

DT Article
TI A phylogeny of Pacific fiddler crabs of the subgenus Minuca (Crustacea,
   Brachyura, Ocypodidae: Uca) with the description of a new species from a
   tropical gulf in Pacific Costa Rica.
AU Landstorfer, Richard B. (r.landstorfer@gmx.de) 
   Schubart, Christoph D.
SO Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research
VL 48
IS 3
PS 213-218
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The phylogeny of all Pacific fiddler crab representatives of the
   subgenus Minuca Bott, 1954 (sensu Beinlich and von Hagen, 2006) is
   reconstructed. For the molecular analysis, Cox1 mitochondrial and 28S
   ribosomal nuclear DNA sequences were used. According to these data, same
   transisthmian sister species relationships are confirmed and a new
   species of the genus Uca Leach, 1814, Uca osa sp. n., is described from
   Golfo Dulce, a tropical gulf in Pacific Costa Rica. Morphological as
   well as molecular data confirm distinctness of this species compared
   with all other members of the subgenus Minuca, to which it belongs.
   Distinctive morphological traits are presented to distinguish Uca osa
   sp. n. from its congeners in the Eastern Pacific.
C1 Landstorfer, Richard B.; Univ Regensburg, Inst Zool, Univ Str 31,
   Regensburg, Germany, Germany.
EM r.landstorfer@gmx.de
RI Schubart, Christoph/B-5595-2012

   Evolutionary Biology
SN 0947-5745

   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ]. 
   Uca osa [North Pacific / Costa Rica / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14612082744
DT Article
TI Phylogeny and systematic revision of Eocene Cricetidae (Rodentia,
   Mammalia) from Central and East Asia: on the origin of cricetid rodents.
AU Rodrigues, Helder Gomes (helder.gomes-rodrigues@univ-montp2.fr) 
   Marivaux, Laurent
   Vianey-Liaud, Monique
SO Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research
VL 48
IS 3
PS 259-268
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB The origin of the Cricetidae and the relationships among earliest
   species from Central and East Asia are still disputed. The taxonomic
   status of some Eocene cricetid taxa is also doubtful. A parsimony
   analysis based on 65 cranial and dental characters and including 22
   early Myomorpha was performed to elucidate these issues. As a result,
   the North American Elymys, known as the first Myodonta, belongs to
   dipodoid rodents, although it shares a suite of characters with the
   first cricetids. This implies that the split between dipodoids and
   muroids occurred in North America during the early middle Eocene, as
   previously supposed. The disputed Simimys and Nonomys could constitute
   an early dipodoid radiation. It appears that the earliest offshoot of
   the cricetid clade is the Asian genus Palasiomys. This taxon has a more
   advanced cricetid plan than contemporaneous dipodoids. The genus
   Raricricetodon no longer exists here because it is polyphyletic; the
   species are included in Palasiomys (P. minor, P. trapezius) and
   Pappocricetodon (P. zhongtiaensis). The genus Pappocricetodon displays a
   complete cricetid plan associated with both the loss of P4 and the
   development of an anterocone on M1. The disputed genera Eocricetodon and
   Oxynocricetodon characterize the beginning of the Oligocene radiations
   of Eucricetodontinae throughout the Holarctic continents.
C1 Rodrigues, Helder Gomes; Univ Montpellier 2, Inst Sci Evolut,
   Montpellier, France, France.
EM helder.gomes-rodrigues@univ-montp2.fr
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0947-5745
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Cricetidae [Phylogeny /  / Systematic revision] [Asia / Central & east /
   ] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae
OR Cricetidae (Muridae): [Fossil]. 
   Palasiomys - Tong 1997 (Muridae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 263; Fossil]. 
   Palasiomys minor - (Tong 1997) (Muridae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Raricricetodon, p. 265; Fossil]. 
   Palasiomys tapezius - (Tong 1997) (Muridae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Raricricetodon, p. 265; Fossil]. 
   Pappocricetodon - Tong 1992 (Muridae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 263;
   Fossil]. 
   Pappocricetodon zhonghtiaensis - (Tong 1997) (Muridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Raricricetodon, p. 265; Fossil]. 
   Raricricetodon zhonghtiaensis - Tong 1997 (Muridae): [Referred to,
   Pappocricetodon, p. 265; Fossil]. 
   Raricricetodon? minor - Tong 1997 (Muridae): [Referred to, Palasiomys,
   p. 265; Fossil]. 
   Raricricetodon? tapezius - Tong 1997 (Muridae): [Referred to,
   Palasiomys, p. 265; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14612082744

AN ZOOR14611081707
DT Article
TI [New taxa of Carabus L. from the Chinese provinces of Yunnan, Sichuan
   and Gansu (Coleoptera, Carabidae).]
FT Nuovi taxa di Carabus L. delle province Cinesi di Yunnan, Sichuan e
   Gansu (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Cavazzuti, Pierfranco (pierfranco41@alice.it) 
   Rapuzzi, Ivan
SO Lambillionea
VL 110
IS 2
SU (Tome 1)
PS 154-168
PD Aout 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ten new Carabus subspecies from the Chinese Provinces of' Yunnan,
   Sichuan and Gansu are described and figured : C. (Apotomopterus)
   patroclus hexianus n. ssp., C. (A.) delavayi menoetius n. ssp., C. (A.)
   mecynodes laeviscrobeatus n. ssp.. C. (A.) piriformis ebian n. ssp., C.
   (Archaeocarabus) mirandus herbeus n. ssp., C. (Cupreocarabus) alpherakii
   wazhangicus n. ssp., Carabus (Pseudocoptolabrus) armiger centurio n.
   ssp., e C. (Coptolabrus) szechwanensis aeriviolaceus n. ssp. from South
   Sichuan; C. (Apotomopterus) tuxeni shiguanus n. ssp. from North West
   Yunnan; C. (Scambocarabus) modestulus atrophus n. ssp. from South Gansu.
   The systematic status of Carabus (Apotompterus) delavavi Fairmaire,
   1886, species group is discussed : this specie is divided into three
   different species : C. (A.) delavayi Fairmaire, 1886. C. (A.) putroc/us
   Breuning, 1933, and C. (A.) medea Kleinfeld, 1999b. The specific status
   of C. (A.) achilleanus Cavazzuti, 2002, is changed into Carabus
   (Apotomopterus) delavavi achilleanus Cavazzuti, 2002, (n. comb.). The
   new name occasus is proposed for C. (Coptolabrus) formosus occiduus
   Cavazzuti & Rapuzzi, 2009, preoccupied by C. (Tachtypus) cancellatus
   occiduus Bernau, 1913.

DT Article
TI A new genus of earthworm (Oligochaeta: Almidae) from Kerala, India.
AU Nair, K. Vijayakumaran
   Manazhy, Jaya
   Manazhy, Aja
   Reynolds, John Warren
SO Megadrilogica
VL 14
IS 3
PS 53-58
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus of Almidae Duboscq 1902, Progizzardus Nair, gen. nov., is
   erected to take a new species, Progizzardus varadiamensis Nair, sp.
   nov., from Thrissur, one of the districts in central Kerala, India. The
   relationship of this genus with Glyphidrilus (Almidae) is discussed.
   This new genus also shows kinship with Criodrilus (Criodrilidae). The
   newspecies, Progizzardus varadiamensis Nair, sp. nov., is close toG.
   papillatus Rosa and G. annandaleiMichaelsen. Taxonomic position
   alongwith the identification key to the genera of tropical species is
   also provided.
SC Zoology
SN 0380-9633
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Progizzardus varadiamensis [Kerala /  / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta
OR Almidae (Oligochaeta): [Key to genera, P. 55]. 
   Progizzardus - Nair 2010 (Oligochaeta): [Gen nov, Of family Almidae,
   Type species Progizzardus varadiamensis Nair 2010, p. 54]. 
   Progizzardus varadiamensis - Nair 2010 (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, Kerala,
   P. 55].

U1 1
U2 22
AB The genus Ciona, a widely distributed group of solitary ascidians, has
   long been an important model in embryology and developmental biology.
   Ciona has also recently attracted the attention of evolutionary
   biologists because of the remarkably high levels of heterozygosity found
   within single individuals. Surprisingly, genealogical relationships in
   Ciona have received little attention. Here, we expand our knowledge of
   relationships among the members of the Ciona genus and estimate levels
   of polymorphism in natural populations. Previous studies have documented
   the outgroup status of Ciona savignyi among the shallow-water Ciona and
   revealed the existence of two distinct forms (Types A and B) of the
   widespread Ciona intestinalis. Here, using gene genealogies of six
   nuclear gene loci, we show Types A and B to be well-supported
   monophyletic groups. In spite of their morphological similarity, Type A
   vs. Type B divergences range from 0.035 to 0.124. In contrast, the
   morphologically distinct Ciona roulei is embedded within Type B in all
   genealogies, and a new species, Ciona sp., appears to be associated with
   Type B/C. roulei to the exclusion of Type A. Levels of polymorphism in
   natural populations are similar to levels reported in other organisms
   that are considered to be highly polymorphic. (C) 2010 Elsevier Inc. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Nydam, Marie L.; Cornell Univ, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary Biol, Ithaca,
   NY, USA, USA.
EM mln32@cornell.edu
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 1055-7903
BD Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Evolutionary adaptation
DE Ciona [Nucleic acids / Nuclear gene sequence data / ] [Molecular
   genetics /  / ] [Population genetics / Population genetic structure / ]
   [Divergence /  / ] [Variation / Polymorphism / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Protochordates; Tunicates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Urochordata, Ascidiacea
OR Ciona (Ascidiacea).

TI Contribution to the Afrotropical fauna of Arctiidae: notes and
   corrections on the species spectrum of the genera Creatonotos Huebner,
   (1819), Afrowatsonius Dubatolov, 2006 and Dubatolovia gen. n.
   (Lepidoptera, Arctiidae, Arctiinae).
FT Beitrag zur afrotropischen Arctiidenfauna: Bemerkungen und Korrekturen
   zum Artenspektrum der Genera Creatonotos Huebner, (1819), Afrowatsonius
   Dubatolov, 2006 und Dubatolovia gen. n. (Lepidoptera: Arctiidae,
   Arctiinae).
AU de Freina, Josef J. (defreina.j@online.de) 
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 31
IS 1-2
PS 1-8
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Afrotropical species of Creatonotos HUEBNER, (1819), the type
   species Creatonotos gangis (LINNAEUS, 1763), and Arabo-Iranian species
   of the Indoaustralian gangis-group are compared with those of
   Afrowatsonius DUBATOLOV, 2006 and the established Dubatolovia gen. n.
   Known external generic characters and structure of the male genitalia
   are confirmed and additional information on the studied female
   genitalia, androconial organs (coremata) and the 8th abdominal tergit
   are given. The diagnostic morphological characteristics are figured and
   representative specimens of the genera are photographed in colour. An
   annotated check list of the species-group of C. leucanioides HOLLAND,
   1893, representing Creatonotos in the Afrotropical region, Afrowatsonius
   and Dubatolovia gen. n. is provided. In addition, the generic
   relationships of some species like Amerila atrivena (HAMPSON, 1907),
   formerly or presently wrongly placed in Creatonotos, are discussed. The
   following taxonomical changes are given: Dubatolovia gen. n. is proposed
   to accommodate Dubatolovia neurophaea (HAMPSON, 1911) comb. n. (type
   species; monospecific), currently in Creatonotos; Afrowatsonius
   marginalis confluens ROTHSCHILD, 1933 syn. n. is synonymized with
   Afrowatsonius marginalis marginalis (WALKER, 1855); Creatonotos
   leucanioides notivitta PINHEY, 1975 syn. n., published as Creatonotos
   punctivitta ab. +notivitta STRAND, 1915 and raised to subspecies rank by
   PINHEY, is attached to Creatonotos leucanioides HOLLAND, 1893;
   Afrospilarctia flavida (BARTEL, 1903) comb. n., described in
   Creatonotos, is transferred to Afrospilarctia DUBATOLOV, 2006. The
   application of the valid species name Afrowatsonius fulvomarginalis
   (WICHGRAF, 1921) (syn. fuscomarginalis GAEDE, 1926; incorrect subsequent
   spelling of fulvomarginalis) is demanded.

TI Notes on Arhopala Boisduval, 1832 from Sulawesi and Maluku, including
   new subspecies of A. argentea Staudinger, 1888, A. chamaeleona
   Bethune-Baker, 1903, and A. azenia (Hewitson, (1863)) (Lepidoptera,
   Lycaenidae).
AU Tennent, W. John (jtstorment@gmail.com) 
   Rawlins, Andrew
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 31
IS 1-2
PS 9-16
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New island distribution records are presented for 23 species of the
   lycaenid genus Arhopala BOISDUVAL, 1832, in the Sulawesi Region and
   Maluku Province, Indonesia. The following new subspecies are described
   and illustrated: Arhopala argentea boordi ssp. n.; Arhopala argentea
   verityae ssp. n.; Arhopala chamaeleona susyae ssp. n.; Arhopala azenia
   patsyae ssp. n.; all holotypes (males) in BMNH, London. A large specimen
   of A. wildei MISKIN, 1891, is also illustrated from the island of
   Morotai, significantly further west than its previously known
   distribution. A. acron (HEWITSON, 1862) is illustrated to facilitate
   separation of this species from A. azenia (HEWITSON, (1863)).

TI A new species of the genus Cricula Walker, 1855 from East Timor
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Naumann, Stefan (sn@saturniidae.com) 
   Lane, David
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 31
IS 1-2
PS 17-19

U1 0

AB A new species of the South-East Asian genus Cricula WALKER, 1855 is
   described: Cricula timorensis sp. n. from East Timor. The male holotype
   and its genitalia are figured in colour. It will be donated to the
   Museum fur Naturkunde at Humboldt-University of Berlin, Germany. C.
   timorensis is compared with its closest relatives, C. hayatiae PAUKSTADT
   & SUHARDJONO, 1992, C. maxalorensis NAUMANN & LOEFFLER, 2010 and C.
   luzonica JORDAN, 1909.

TI Revisional notes on the species-group of Saturnia grotei Moore, 1859 of
   the genus Saturnia Schrank, 1802 (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
AU Naumann, Stefan (sn@saturniidae.com) 
   Naessig, Wolfgang A.
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 31
IS 1-2
PS 31-62
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxa belonging to the species-group of Saturnia grotei arc
   catalogued in order of publication. Lectotypes are designated for:
   Saturnia grotei MOORE, 1859 (male, in London), Saturnia anna ATKINSON
   (in MOORE), 1865 (male, in Berlin), Saturnia bieti OBERTHUR, 1886
   (female, in London), Caligula anna yunnana MELT., 1939 (male, in Bonn)
   and Caligula anna tsinlingshanis MELL, 1939 (male, in Bonn). A neotype
   male is designated for Caligula anna dejeani BOUVIER & RiEL, 1931 to
   stabilize nomenclature (in Frankfurt am Main), because the original type
   material is lost. Revisional notes on the species including descriptions
   of 4 new species: Saturnia paragrotei sp. n. (HT male, in Berlin), S.
   rosalata sp. n. (HT male, in Frankfurt), S. tibetanna sp. n. (HT male,
   in Berlin) and S. sinanna sp. n. (HT male, in Frankfurt), are provided,
   including new information on the preimaginal morphology of some species.
   All species and, where known, preimaginal instars are illustrated, as
   well as male genitalia. The phylogeny of the group is shortly discussed,
   based on morphology and DNA barcode. A check-list of the revised
   species-group (with new synonymies and revised combinations) is provided
   at the end of the publication.

DT Article
TI Parnassius phoebus (Fabricius, 1793), a misidentified species
   (Lepidoptera: Papilionidae).
AU Hanus, Jean (jeanhanus@orange.fr) 
   Theye, Marie-Luce
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 31
IS 1-2
PS 71-84
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Papilio phoebus was briefly described in 1793 by Johan Christian
   FABRICIUS after a watercolour painted by William JONES representing a
   butterfly of the DRURY collection coming from Siberia. JONES' painting
   of P phoebus is published here for the first time. The specimen figured
   as P. phoebus is in reality what is known today as Parnassius ariadne
   (LEDERER, 1853). It was caught in West Altai in 1771, during the Peter
   Simon PALLAS expedition to Siberia. The Alpine "Parnassius phoebus" of
   all authors since 1793 is a misidentification, and is replaced herein by
   the oldest available name applicable to this taxon, namely Parnassius
   corybas FISCHER VON WALDHEIM, 1823, reinstated status. Consequences on
   the Parnassius nomenclature are discussed.
C1 Hanus, Jean; 2 rue de Belgrade, F-38000 Grenoble, France, France.
EM jeanhanus@orange.fr

   1783-1785 / ].

TI A new species of Neruda Turner, 1976 from northeast Brazil (Lepidoptera:
   Nymphalidae, Heliconiinae, Heliconiini).
AU Moreira, Gilson R.P. (gilson.moreira@ufrgs.br) 
   Mielke, Carlos G.C.
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 31
IS 1-2
PS 85-91
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of passion vine butterfly, Neruda metis sp. n., from Serra
   do Penitente, Balsas municipality, Maranhao state, Brazil, is described
   and illustrated. Integumentary ultrastructural characteristics of the
   genitalia of both sexes are compared with the congeneric species. N.
   metis sp. n. general colour pattern resembles the erato-like
   "dennis-ray" subspecies of N. aoede (HUEBNER, (1813)), differing from
   these by having the outer margin of the hind-wing with paired,
   conspicuous white spots located within each cell, and the forewing with
   two oblique, median yellow bands, instead of a yellow ring formed in the
   latter, among other differences in the male and female genitalia. The
   female holotype is deposited in the collection Padre Jesus S. MOURE,
   Departamento de Zoologia, Universidade Federal do Parana, Curitiba,
   Parana, Brazil.
C1 Moreira, Gilson R.P.; Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de
   Biociencias, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Av. Bento
   Goncalves, 9500, Bairro Agronomia, Porto Alegre, RS 91501-970, Brazil,
   Brazil.

DT Article
TI Gaudeamus lavocati sp nov (Rodentia, Hystricognathi) from the early
   Oligocene of Zallah, Libya: first African caviomorph?
AU Coster, Pauline (pauline.coster@univ-poitiers.fr) 
   Benammi, Mouloud
   Lazzari, Vincent
   Billet, Guillaume
   Martin, Thomas
   Salem, Mustafa
   Bilal, Awad Abolhassan
   Chaimanee, Yaowalak
   Schuster, Mathieu
   Valentin, Xavier
   Brunet, Michel
   Jaeger, Jean-Jacques
SO Naturwissenschaften
VL 97
IS 8
PS 697-706
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new African species of hystricognathous rodent, Gaudeamus lavocati sp.
   nov., is described herein from the early Oligocene deposits of Zallah
   locality (Sirt basin, Central Libya). The dental morphology of this
   species is very close to that of some earliest South American
   caviomorphs. It allows a reinterpretation of molar crest homologies
   among earliest caviomorphs, pentalophodonty being confirmed as the
   plesiomorphic molar condition in Caviomorpha. This morphological
   resemblance argues for close affinities between Gaudeamus and earliest
   South American hystricognaths. Cladistic analysis supports Gaudeamus
   lavocati sp. nov. as the first known African representative of
   Caviomorpha, implying that its ancestors were part of the African
   phiomyid group that crossed the South Atlantic by a direct immigration
   route. Alternatively, the series of derived dental features of Gaudeamus
   could also be interpreted as evolutionary synchronous convergences of an
   African hystricognath lineage towards the specialized pattern of some
   caviomorphs. However, the high level of similarities concerning teeth
   morphology and enamel microstructure and the similar age of
   fossiliferous strata on both continents make this interpretation less
   probable. The phylogenetic position of this taxon is of considerable
   importance because it represents an enigmatic component of the
   phiomorph-caviomorph radiation in Africa and appears as a new clue
   toward the understanding of caviomorph origins.
C1 Coster, Pauline; Univ Poitiers UFR SFA, CNRS, 40 Ave Recteur Pineau,
   Poitiers, France, France.
EM pauline.coster@univ-poitiers.fr
RI Bilal, Awad/AAP-9486-2020; Lund, Laura/H-7335-2012
OI Bilal, Awad/0000-0002-4903-2682; BILLET, Guillaume/0000-0002-3200-1548;
   Coster, Pauline/0000-0003-4015-252X
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0028-1042
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Palaearctic region; Africa; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Caviomorpha [Africa /  / new record] [Oligocene / Early Oligocene / ]. 
   Gaudeamus lavocati [Libya /  / new species] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Phiomyidae
OR Caviomorpha (Rodentia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Gaudeamus lavocati (Phiomyidae): [Sp nov, Libya, Oligocene, P. 698;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701002483
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14802016612
DT Article
TI Turritella nzimaorum Ryall & Vos, 2010 a junior synonym of Turritella
   caelata Morch in Dunker, 1858.
AU Nolf, Frank (frank.nolf@pandora.be) 
   Verstraeten, Johan
SO Neptunea
VL 9
IS 2
PS 28-32
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Recently, P. Ryall & C. Vos (2010) described a new species of Turritella
   from western Africa. This species was compared with other similar
   representatives of the genus Turritella but the authors failed to notice
   the existence of Turritella caelata Morch in Dunker, 1858 a species from
   the Gulf of Guinea with the same characteristics as those of T.
   nzimaorum Ryall & Vos, 2010. Because of the unmistakable likeness with
   the type and the original figures o1 T. caelata, the name T. nzimaorum
   is rejected as taxon.
C1 Nolf, Frank; Pr. Stefanieplein, 43/8, B-8400 Oostende, Belgium, Belgium.
EM frank.nolf@pandora.be
SC Zoology
SN 1378-2029
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Marine zones
DE Turritella caelata [Atlantic Ocean / Africa / Distribution;
   systematics].

PT J

DT Article
TI Ammonites from the Maastrichtian (Upper Cretaceous) Quiriquina Formation
   in central Chile.
AU Salazar, Christian (csalazar@geos.uni-heidelberg.de) 
   Stinnesbeck, Wolfgang
   Quinzio-Sinn, Luis Arturo
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 257
IS 2
PS 181-236
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Quiriquina Formation in central Chile is famous for its abundant and
   diverse ammonite assemblages of Maastrichtian age. In the type locality
   around the Concepcion Bay in the Bio-Bio Region of central Chile we have
   identified a total of 30 species referred to 17 genera. Hypophylloceras
   (Neophylloceras) ramosum, H. (N.) hetonaiense, H. (N.) inflatum, H. (N.)
   surya, Anagaudryceras politissimum, Gaudryceras kayei, Zelandites
   varuna, Pseudophyllites indra, Kitchinites darwini, Kossmaticeras
   (Natalites) erbeni, Grossouvrites gemmatus, Gunnarites spinosissimus,
   Maorites densicostatus, Pachydiscus (P.) jacquoti chilensis, Menuites
   fresvillensis, Diplomoceras cylindraceum, Phylloptychoceras sp.,
   Baculites huenickeni, Baculites vicentei and Eubaculites carinatus have
   been recorded previously from the Quiriquina Formation. Hoploscaphites
   constrictus quiriquiniensis sensu WILCKENS (1904). Phyllopachyceras
   forbesianum, Anagaudryceras subtilineatum, Gunnarites cf. bhavaniformis
   and Baculites anceps are new records for the Quiriquina Formation added
   here. Kitchinites vicentensis n. sp., Kitchinites ifrimae n. sp.,
   Grossouvrites joharae n. sp., Pachydiscus (P.) gutierrezi n. sp. and
   Menuites gerardoi n. sp. are new. Gaudryceras kayei specimens are
   recorded with diameters in excess of 200 mm and present marked changes
   during growth. Anagaudryceras politissimum and Zelandites varuna also
   show strong ontogenetic changes. Kitchinites darwini of the Quiriquina
   Formation differs from material from Antarctica; we propose that the
   latter should by separated. The presence of Hypophylloceras
   (Neophylloceras) surya, Zelandites varuna, Pachydiscus (P.) jacquoti,
   Diplomoceras cylindraceum, Baculites anceps, Eubaculites carinatus and
   Hoploscaphites constrictus quiriquiniensis indicates a Maastrichtian age
   for the Quiriquina Formation. Menuites fresvillensis confirms the late
   Maastrichtian age for most of the Quiriquina Formation. The assemblage
   presented shows cosmopolitan and Indo-Pacific affinities with a few
   European and Tethyan links.
C1 Salazar, Christian; Univ Heidelberg, Inst Geowissensch, INF 234,
   Heidelberg, Germany, Germany.
EM csalazar@geos.uni-heidelberg.de
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Paleontology
SN 0077-7749

   Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ammonoidea [Development / Ontogenesis / new record; systematics] [Fossil
   assemblages /  / ] [Zoogeography / Faunal affinities / ] [Chile /
   Bio-Bio Region, Concepcion Bay area / ] [Cretaceous / Maastrichtian / ].
   
   Anagaudryceras subtilineatum; Baculites anceps; Gunnarites;
   Hoploscaphites constrictus quiriquiniensis; Phyllopachyceras forbesianum
   [Chile / Bio-Bio Region, Concepcion Bay area / new record] [Cretaceous /
   Maastrichtian / ].

   Pachydiscus (Pachydiscus) gutierrezi [Chile /  / new species]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Phylloceratida
OR Ammonoidea (Cephalopoda): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Grossouvrites joharae - Kilian & Reboul 1909 (Ammonitida): [Sp nov,
   Chile, Cretaceous, P. 207; Fossil]. 
   Gunnarites (Ammonitida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Kitchinites ifrimae (Ammonitida): [Sp nov, Chile, Cretaceous, P. 203;
   Fossil]. 
   Kitchinites vicentensis (Ammonitida): [Sp nov, Chile, Cretaceous, P.
   202; Fossil]. 
   Menuites gerardoi (Ammonitida): [Sp nov, Chile, Cretaceous, P. 216;
   Fossil]. 
   Pachydiscus (Pachydiscus) gutierrezi (Ammonitida): [Sp nov, Chile,
   Cretaceous, P. 213; Fossil]. 
   Anagaudryceras subtilineatum (Lytoceratida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Baculites anceps (Lytoceratida): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Hoploscaphites constrictus quiriquiniensis (Lytoceratida): [Fossil; New
   record].

PT J

DT Article
TI The Ordovician caryocaridid phyllocarids (Crustacea): diversity and
   evolutionary tendencies.
AU Racheboeuf, Patrick R. (patrick.racheboeuf@univ-brest.fr) 
   Crasquin, Sylvie
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 257
IS 2
PS 237-248
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB An overall look at the Ordovician phyllocarid representatives assigned
   to the Family Caryocarididae led to the recognition of an unexpected
   biodiversity during the Tremadocian Hirnantian time interval. Three new
   genera are described: Jellicaris n.g. from Australia, Saltericaris n.g.
   from Bohemia, and Soomicaris n.g. from South Africa, which add to the
   three previously described taxa, namely Caryocaris, Janviericaris, and
   Ivocaris; hence the Family Caryocarididae now includes six genera. The
   stratigraphical range of these genera, with respect to the graptolite
   zonation, displays that morphological characters vary accordingly, which
   is considered to reflect evolutionary tendencies which are exposed and
   discussed herein. Hypothetical phyletic relationships between
   caryocaridid genera are briefly discussed and are suggestive of two
   parallel lineages within the Family Caryopcarididac.
C1 Racheboeuf, Patrick R.; Univ Bretagne Occidentale, Univ Europeenne
   Bretagne, 6 Ave Gorgeu,CS 93837, Brest, France, France.
EM patrick.racheboeuf@univ-brest.fr
RI Crasquin, Sylvie/F-6913-2010; Crasquin, Sylvie/AAT-9631-2020
OI Crasquin, Sylvie/0000-0003-4358-3827
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 0077-7749
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Documentation; Publications; Evolution; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic

   [Phylogeny /  / ] [Ordovician /  / stratigraphical distribution]. 
   Jellicaris; Saltericaris; Soomicaris [Ordovician /  / New genus]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Phyllocarida

   Caryocaris - Salter 1863 (Phyllocarida): [Emended diagnosis, P. 243;
   Fossil]. 
   Caryocaris cedarbergensis - Whittle, Gabbott, Aldridge & Theron 2007
   (Phyllocarida): [Designated type species for new genus, Soomicaris, p.
   246; Fossil]. 
   Caryocaris stewarti - Jell 1980 (Phyllocarida): [Designated type species
   for new genus, Jellicaris, p. 245; Fossil]. 
   Caryocaris subula - Chlupac 1970 (Phyllocarida): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Saltericaris, p. 246; Fossil].

   species Caryocaris stewarti Jell 1980, p. 245, Ordovician; Fossil]. 
   Saltericaris (Phyllocarida): [Gen nov, Of family Caryocarididae, Type
   species Caryocaris subula Chlupac 1970, p. 246, Ordovician; Fossil]. 
   Soomicaris (Phyllocarida): [Gen nov, Of family Caryocarididae, Type

PM 20480376
DT Article
TI Auerbachia bajadi sp n. (Myxozoa: Auerbachiidae) infecting the
   gallbladder of orangespotted trevally Carangoides bajad (Teleostei:
   Carangidae) in the Red Sea.
AU Abdel-Baki, Abdel-Azeem Sh. (azema1@yahoo.com) 
SO Parasitology Research
VL 107
IS 3
PS 571-575
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Light microscopic description was presented for a new myxosporean
   species, Auerbachia bajadi. The parasite was collected from the
   gallbladder of orangespotted trevally Carangoides bajad (ForsskAyenl,
   1775) in Al-Quseir city, Red Sea coast, Egypt. The prevalence was 30/80
   (37%) and the infection was reported as an enormous amount of free
   mature spores floating in the bile. Spores were club-shaped with a broad
   anterior part and a narrow caudal part. Shell valves were asymmetrical
   and the larger valve was drawn into a wide caudal projection. The mean
   spore measurements were 22.7 [mu]m in total length and 9.5 [mu]m in
   width. Polar capsule was single and elliptical-shaped with five polar
   filament turns. The polar capsule measured 9.5 [mu]m in length and 4.5
   [mu]m in width. The spores were distinctly different from the four
   recorded species of genus Auerbachia. One of the cited species of this
   genus was excluded as it was related to genus Coccomyxa than genus
   Auerbachia. Also, the accurate citation date of this genus was
   discussed.
C1 Abdel-Baki, Abdel-Azeem Sh.; King Saud Univ, Dept Zool, POB 12455,
   Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, Saudi Arabia.
EM azema1@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0932-0113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian
   Ocean
DE Auerbachia bajadi [Piscean hosts / Carangoides bajad / New parasite
   species] [Red Sea / Egypt / New species from piscean host]. 
   Carangoides bajad [Myxozoan parasites / Auerbachia bajadi / New parasite
   species] [Red Sea / Egypt / New myxozoan parasite species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Carangidae, Myxozoa, Myxosporea, Bivalvulida
OR Carangoides bajad (Carangidae): [Host]. 
   Auerbachia - Meglitsch 1968 (Bivalvulida): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 574]. 
   Auerbachia bajadi (Bivalvulida): [Sp nov, Egypt (marine), Parasite of
   Carangoides bajad (Pisces), p. 573; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701001219
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14701006034
DT Article
TI New Lachesilla (Psocodea: 'Psocoptera': Lachesillidae) from Peru and
   Mexico, based on males with one clunial apophysis.
AU Garcia Aldrete, Alfonso N. (anga@ibiologia2.unam.mx) 
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 81
IS 2
PS 309-314
PD agosto 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Three species of Lachesilla from Peru and Mexico are described and
   illustrated. They are based on male specimens, characterized by having a
   clunial apophysis over the area of the epiproct. The Mexican species
   constitutes a new species group, and the 2 Peruvian species belong in
   the pedicularia group. Types are deposited in the National Insect
   Collection (CNIN), housed in the Instituto de Biologia, Universidad
   Nacional Autonoma de Mexico.
C1 Garcia Aldrete, Alfonso N.; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Biol,
   Apartado Postal 70-153, Mexico City, DF, Mexico, Mexico.
EM anga@ibiologia2.unam.mx
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   Neotropical region; North America; South America
DE Lachesilla carpinteroi; Lachesilla williamsi [Peru /  / New species]. 
   Lachesilla cerorma [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Psocoptera
OR Lachesilla carpinteroi (Psocoptera): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 309]. 
   Lachesilla cerorma (Psocoptera): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 310]. 
   Lachesilla cerorma group (Psocoptera): [New species group, P. 314]. 
   Lachesilla williamsi (Psocoptera): [Sp nov, Peru, P. 310]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14701006034
OA DOAJ Gold

PT J
AN ZOOR14701006040
DT Article
TI Ground surface spider fauna in an arid tropical community in Baja
   California Sur, Mexico.
FT Fauna de aranas del suelo de una comunidad arida-tropical en Baja
   California Sur, Mexico.
AU Jimenez, Maria Luisa (ljimenez04@cibnor.mx) 
   Navarrete, Jose Gabriel
SO Revista Mexicana de Biodiversidad
VL 81
IS 2
PS 417-426
PD agosto 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 5
AB Seasonal distribution, specific richness, and diversity of xeric shrub
   ground spiders were studied at a site in the Cape Region. Weekly
   collections of spiders were made in 1991-1992 using pit-fall traps. We
   captured 4 322 specimens in 53 families. Families with the highest
   number of individuals were: Miturgidae (42%) Oonopidae (23.5%),
   Caponiidae (8.0%), and Gnaphosidae (7.9%). The most abundant species
   were Syspira tigrina Chamberlin (37.1%); Oonops nov. sp. (13.7%),
   Scaphiella hespera Chamberlin (7.8%), and Tarsonops sternalis Chamberlin
   (5.2%), representing 63.7% of the total specimens captured. Gnaphosidae
   was the richest in species (11) followed by Salticidae (7). Species
   richness was nearly constant during all the year, with a small increase
   in summer (29) and a small decline in winter (24); seasonal diversity
   was also constant (H' = 3.3-3.7). The highest relative abundance
   occurred in spring and autumn and the highest specific richness was in
   autumn. The diversity and relative abundance of spiders were high, in
   spite of the high abundance of Miturgidae. Distribution of the major
   species had a marked seasonality.
C1 Jimenez, Maria Luisa; Ctr Invest Biol Noroeste, Lab Aracnol & Entomol,
   SC Apartado Postal 128, La Paz, Baja California, Mexico, Mexico.
EM ljimenez04@cibnor.mx
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
BD Ecology; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   North America
DE Araneae [Community structure /  / Seasonal changes] [Desert habitat /

PT J
AN ZOOR14701004182
DT Article
TI New crabs (Crustacea, Decapoda) from the Upper Cretaceous (Campanian) of
   the Moyenne Moulouya, northeast Morocco.
AU Osso-Morales, Alex
   Artal, Pedro
   Vega, Francisco J. (vegver@servidor.unam.mx) 
SO Revista Mexicana de Ciencias Geologicas
VL 27
IS 2
PS 213-224
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The presence of the genera Costacopluma and Ophthalmoplax in Upper
   Cretaceous (Campanian) Moroccan strata is documented on the basis of
   specimens collected from the Calcaires a slumps de Taghit Formation,
   Moyenne Moulouva (Morocco). Two new species are described. Ophthalmoplax
   minimus and Costacopluma maroccana. The first record for Opthalmoplax in
   the west Tethyan realm is reported, and systematic affinities of this
   genus and its species are discussed. An absolute age of the late
   Campanian was obtained for this assemblage from 87Sr/86Sr analysis
   applied to well preserved cuticle calcitic remains of Ophthalmoplax
   minimus. Costacopluma maroccana represents the 14th species for this
   genus and the fourth Cretaceous species. Its morphology rein forces
   hypothesis of two main phyletic groups for this genus.
C1 Vega, Francisco J.; Josep Vicenc Foix, 12-H 1Er 1A, Tarragona,
   Catalonia, Spain, Spain.
EM vegver@servidor.unam.mx

DT Article
TI Endoparasites of small mammals from northeastern Peru. 1: Helmintes of
   marsupials.
FT Endopharasitos de miromamiferos del noroeste de Peru. 1: helmintos de
   marsupiales.
AU Tantalean, Manuel (mmonicardiaz@arnet.comar) 
   Diaz, Monica
   Sanchez, Nofre
   Portocarrero, Harold
SO Revista Peruana de Biologia
VL 17
IS 2
PS 207-213
PD Agosto 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 3
AB In this paper, we report the results of parasitological examination
   performed on 40 specimens of marsupials species: Caluromys lanatus,
   Didelphis marsupialis, Marmosops noctivagus, Metachirus nudicaudatus,
   Marmosa (Micoureus) regina, Monodelphis adusta, Philander andersoni and
   Philander opossum from department of Loreto, Peru. The endoparasites
   were: Nematoda: Aspidodera sp., Cruzia tentaculata, Physaloptera
   mirandai, Physaloptera sp., Pterygodermatites sp., Trichuris sp.,
   Turgida turgida, and Viannaia sp.; Trematoda: Podospathalium pedatum;
   Acanthocephala: Giganthorhynchus ortizi and Pentastomida: nymph. For the
   first time Trichuris sp., Pterygodematities sp., Turgida turgida,
   Viannaia sp. and Podospathalium pedatum are reported from marsupials in
   Peru. Also, for the first time the following parasite-hosts associations
   are recorded: Pterygodermatites sp.-Marmosa regina, Viannaia
   sp.-Marmosops noctivagus, Trichuris sp.-Marmosops cf. noctivagus,
   Podospathalium pedatum-Monodelphis adusta, Giganthorhynchus
   ortizi-Marmosops cf. noctivagus, and nymphs of pentastomida-Marmosa
   regina and Metachirus nudicaudatus.

TI Spargana infection in frogs of genus Pristimantis (Anura,
   Strabomantidae) from Peru.
FT Infestacion por esparganos en ranas del genero Pristimantis (Anura,
   Strabomantidae) del Peru.
AU Gomez-Puerta, Luis (lucho92@yahoo.com) 
   Chavez, German
   Enciso, Marco A.
   Mendoza, Ana P.
SO Revista Peruana de Biologia
VL 17
IS 2
PS 265-266
PD Agosto 2010
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study, we report the parasitism by sparganum of tapeworm
   Spirometra sp. in amphibians: Pristimantis nephophilus and Pristimantis
   rhodostichus, from the department of San Martin, Peru. We collected
   three filiform structures located at the subcutaneous and identified as
   sparganum. The finding of this metacestode is the first record in
   amphibians of Peru, and shows that frogs P. nephophilus and P.
   rhodostichus are new intermediate hosts for Spirometra sp.
C1 Gomez-Puerta, Luis; Facultad de Medicina Veterinaria, Universidad

DT Article
TI First discovery of fossil Nesolagus (Leporidae, Lagomorpha) from
   Southeast Asia.
AU Jin, ChangZhu (jinchangzhu@ivpp.ac.cn) 
   Tomida, Yukimitsu
   Wang, Yuan
   Zhang, YingQi
SO Science China - Earth Sciences
VL 53
IS 8
PS 1134-1140
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A new leporid species, Nesolagus sinensis sp. nov., is described here
   representing the only leporid member of the Early Pleistocene
   Gigantopithecus fauna from Sanhe Cave, Chongzuo, Guangxi, South China
   and also the first fossil taxon of the Southeast Asian genus Nesolagus.
   Compared with two extant Nesolagus species from Indonesia and Vietnam
   and other related leprids, the new species has a relatively small size
   and an extraordinarily weak anterior internal reentrant (AIR) on p3, but
   it also retains the simplified paedomorphic pattern during the
   ontogenetic process as in extant species, which suggests that the new
   species is more primitive than and probably directly ancestral to extant
   Nesolagus species. The new species seems closely related to Alilepus
   longisinuosus from the Late Miocene strata of Lufeng, Yunnan, and
   probably diverged from a leporid similar to its ancestral form. It also
   indicates that Nesolagus originated in Southwest China.
C1 Jin, ChangZhu; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Vertebrate Paleontol &
   Paleoanthropol, Beijing, China, China.
EM jinchangzhu@ivpp.ac.cn
RI ZHANG, Yingqi/D-4350-2013
OI ZHANG, Yingqi/0000-0001-7783-8336

SN 1674-7313

   Quaternary; Tertiary

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC STUDIES OF THE GENUS PHYMATURUS (IGUANIA: LIOLAEMIDAE):
   DESCRIPTION OF FOUR NEW SPECIES.
AU Lobo, Fernando (flobo@unsa.edu.ar) 
   Abdala, Cristian
   Valdecantos, Soledad
SO South American Journal of Herpetology
VL 5
IS 2
PS 102-126
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB After the study of a diverse collection of Phymaturus from three
   Argentinian institutions and additional samples collected in the last
   two years we discovered several populations of uncertain taxonomic
   status. Based on 93 morphological characters of squamation, color
   pattern, gular and nuchal folds, precloacal pores, and morphometric
   data, we conclude that at least four of those are independent lineages
   which require formal description. Characters related to sexual
   dimorphism and dichromatism as well as the ontogenetic change of several
   others, from juvenile to adult specimens, are described. According to
   the most recent revision of the genus (Lobo and Quinteros, 2005a) and
   considering the descriptions made in the last four years, the taxonomic
   composition of the genus was raised to 23 species. In this study we
   provide the formal description of four additional new taxa, including
   their diagnosis and detailed comparisons with other members of their
   species groups. Two new species belong to the patagonicus group
   (provinces of Chubut and Rio Negro, in Patagonia between 46[degree] and
   41[degree] of latitude) while the other two belong to the palluma group
   (Neuquen and Catamarca provinces, western Argentina, 39[degree] and
   27-26[degree]30[minute] of latitude respectively). With the exception of
   one case for which four localities are reported, all new species are
   restricted to their type localities. This fact confirms a common
   historical distributional pattern for most species of the genus.
C1 Lobo, Fernando; IBIGEO (Instituto de Bio y Geociencias del NOA),
   CONICET, Universidad Nacional de Salta, Avda. Bolivia 5150, 4400, Salta,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM flobo@unsa.edu.ar
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology

   Key; General morphology; Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America

   [Morphological variation /  / ] [Argentina /  / Key to species] [ /  /
   distribution] [Chile /  / ]. 
   Phymaturus patagonicus group [General morphology /  / systematics]
   [Morphological variation /  / ] [Argentina /  / Key to species] [ /  /
   distribution].

   Sauria, Iguanidae

TI Two new species and new records of cicadas from Central America
   (Hemiptera: Cicadomorpha: Cicadidae).
AU Sanborn, Allen F. (asanborn@mail.barry.edu) 
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 45
IS 2
PS 67-76
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of cicadas from Central America are presented. New
   members of the genus Tibicen Latreille, T. heathi sp. n., T. bimaculatus
   sp. n., are described from Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, and Mexico. New
   records for the cicada fauna of Belize (one species), El Salvador (two
   species), Guatemala (nine species), Honduras (seven species), Mexico
   (four species), and Nicaragua (one species) are also provided. The
   additional species represent an increase of 28.6, 12.5, 42.9, 35.0, 3.4,
   and 25.0%, respectively, in the cicada diversity of each country.

PT J
AN ZOOR14701002877
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of Agalliinae from Brazil (Hemiptera:
   Cicadellidae).
AU Goncalves, Ana Clara (anaclara1938@yahoo.com.br) 
   Nielson, Mervin W.
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 45
IS 2
PS 77-82
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus, Paranagallia, and a new species, P. takiyae sp. n., are
   described and illustrated from south Brazil. Paranagallia gen. n. can be
   distinguished from all other known genera of Agalliinae by morphological
   features such as: crown truncate in dorsal view, and in frontal view
   bearing well-developed foveae; face and pronotum strongly flattened;
   pronotum striated; pygofer L-shaped; styles not forked; subgenital
   plates fused to each other; segment X bearing sword-shaped processes;
   female pregenital sternum reduced and first tarsomere of the
   metathoracic tibiae bearing two platellae. Chaetotaxy characters of the
   metathoracic legs are for the first time illustrated through scanning
   electron microscopy.
C1 Goncalves, Ana Clara; Univ Fed Rio de Janeiro, Natl Museum, Rio De
   Janeiro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM anaclara1938@yahoo.com.br
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0521
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Paranagallia takiyae [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Cicadelloidea, Cicadellidae
OR Paranagallia (Cicadellidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Agalliinae, Type
   species Paranagallia takiyae, p. 77]. 
   Paranagallia takiyae (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 78].

TI A new Egidemia China from South Peru with a key to the species of the
   genus (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Cicadellinae: Proconiini).
AU Carpi, Andre
   Mejdalani, Gabriel (mejdalan@acd.ufrj.br) 
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 45
IS 2
PS 83-87
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Egidemia peruana sp. n., a new species from South Peru (Urubamba
   Province, Cusco Region), is described and illustrated. The new taxon can
   be distinguished from the other eight known Egidemia China species
   mainly by the shape of the male pygofer, subgenital plates, styles, and
   aedeagus. Taxonomic notes on the genus and a key to its species are
   included.

TI A new species of the genus Fannia Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Fanniidae)
   belonging to the canicularis species group, collected on pig carrion in
   the Yungas of the province of Jujuy, Argentina.
AU Quiroga, Nancy I.
   Dominguez, M. Cecilia (mcdomin@mendoza-conicet.gov.ar) 
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 45
IS 2
PS 95-100
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This study describes themale, female and third instar larva of Fannia
   yunguensis sp. nov., a new species of Fanniidae that was reared from
   larvae captured on pig carcasses in the Yungas of the province of Jujuy,
   Argentina.modifications to the keys formales and females are also
   provided. The presence of an epiphallus suggests including the new
   species into the pusio subgroup of the canicularis species group.

PT J
AN ZOOR14801000565
DT Article
TI NUTRIA (MYOCASTOR COYPUS) IN BIG BEND NATIONAL PARK; A NON-NATIVE
   SPECIES IN DESERT WETLANDS.
AU Milholland, Matthew T.
   Shumate, Jason P.
   Simpson, Thomas R. (r_simpson@txstate.edu) 
   Manning, Richard W.
SO Texas Journal of Science
VL 62
IS 3
PS 205-222
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 36
AB Nutria are large, semi-aquatic rodents first introduced into the United
   States from South America as a fur resource during the 1890s. Nutria
   first were reported at Rio Grande Village, Big Bend National Park, in
   1993. During 2004 and 2005, more than 30 locations of nutria activity
   were documented along a 16 km section of the Rio Grande River from 7.6
   km upstream of Rio Grande Village to Boquillas Canyon including the Rio
   Grande Village beaver pond. Seventeen nutria were captured, marked, and
   released. Using the Schnabel and Chapman methods, 38-74 nutria were
   estimated to inhabit the RGV area. Stomach contents (n = 14) contained
   common reed (Phragmites australis), water pennywort (Hydroctyle
   umbellata), giant reed (Arundo donax), spikerush (Eleocharis caribaea),
   bermudagrass (Cynodon dactylon), water hyssop (Bacopa monnieri), foxtail
   (Alopecurus sp.), and flatsedge (Cyperus sp.). Seven adult nutria were
   radio-collared and released between May 2004 and June 2005. The mean
   home-range size was estimated to be 10.0 ha (14.8 ha for males, 2.9 for
   females), and the mean maximum daily distance moved was estimated to
   637.4 m (738.3 m for males, 486 m for females).
C1 Simpson, Thomas R.; Texas State Univ San Marcos, Dept Biol, San Marcos,
   TX, 78666, USA, USA.
EM r_simpson@txstate.edu
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Behavioral Sciences; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0040-4403
BD Nutrition; Diet; Behaviour; Habitat; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Myocastor coypus [Food plants / Diet composition / exotic species] [Home
   range / Home range size / ] [Semiaquatic habitat / Wetland / ] [Texas /
   Big Bend National Park / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Myocastoridae
OR Myocastor coypus (Myocastoridae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14801000565
DA 2020-09-17
ER

DT Article
TI A new species of crested gibbon, from the central Annamite mountain
   range.
AU Thinh, Van Ngoc (vanthinhngoc@yahoo.com) 
   Mootnick, Alan R.
   Thanh, Vu Ngoc
   Nadler, Tilo
   Roos, Christian
SO Vietnamese Journal of Primatology
VL 1
IS 4
PS 1-12
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Crested gibbons are endemic to the Indochinese bioregion and occur only
   in Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and southern China. However, their diversity
   is not completely understood and the number of recognized species is
   still under debate. Recent investigations divide crested gibbons into
   six species, namely Nomascus hainanus, N. nasutus, N. concolor, N.
   leucogenys, N. siki and N. gabriellae. However, there is evidence that
   gibbons in the range of N. siki represent two taxa. Based on genetic,
   acoustic and morphological data, a new gibbon species - Nomascus
   annamensis - is herein described.
C1 Thinh, Van Ngoc; Primate Genetics Laboratory, German Primate Center,
   Kellnerweg 4, 37077 Goettingen, Germany, Germany.
EM vanthinhngoc@yahoo.com
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Behavioral Sciences
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Genetics; Evolution; Variation;
   Behaviour; Communication; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Nomascus [Molecular genetics / Cytochrome b gene sequences / taxonomic
   implications] [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ] [Behavioural
   variation / Call characteristics / Comparative study] [Acoustic signals
   /  / ]. 
   Nomascus annamensis [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Primates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Primates, Hylobatidae
OR Nomascus (Hylobatidae). 
   Nomascus annamensis (Hylobatidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14809060396
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI The Pedicinus species (Insecta, Phthiraptera, Anoplura, Pedicinidae) on
   douc langurs (Pygathrix spp.).
AU Mey, Eberhard (mey-rudolstadt@t-online.de) 
SO Vietnamese Journal of Primatology
VL 1
IS 4
PS 57-68
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB All three species of Southeast-Asian douc langurs (Pygathrix spp.)
   harbor a host-specific species of Pedicinus (Neopedicinus). Using
   freshly collected material of known provenance, these were identified as
   Pedicinus tongkinensis Mey, 1994 ex Pygathrix nemaeus, Pedicinus
   atratulus nov. spec. ex Pygathrix nigripes, and Pedicinus curtipenitus
   nov. spec. ex Pygathrix cinerea. The three species described here are
   closely related to each other and belong to the newly created "ancoratus
   species group" within the subgenus Neopedicinus.
C1 Mey, Eberhard; Museum of Natural History at the State Museum
   Heidecksburg, Schlossbezirk 1, D-07407 Rudolstadt, Germany, Germany.
EM mey-rudolstadt@t-online.de

   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Pedicinus (Neopedicinus) [Mammalian hosts / Pygathrix / Host
   specificity; systematics] [Asia / Indochina / ]. 
   Pedicinus (Neopedicinus) atratulus [Mammalian hosts / Pygathrix nigripes
   / New parasite species] [Vietnam /  / New species from mammalian host].

   cinerea / New parasite species] [Vietnam /  / New species from mammalian
   host].

   specificity; parasite systematics] [Asia / Indochina / ].

   genus Ellatrivia Iredale, 1931 with the description of a new species

   Grego, Jozef
SO Visaya

IS 1
PS 21-61
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB All known fossil and recent species of the genus Ellatrivia Iredale,
   1931 are critically reviewed. The types of most species are presented as
   photographs for the first time and a more modern description is given
   when necessary. The genus Austrotrivia Fehse, 2002 is now recognized as
   a junior synonym of Ellatrivia. A new species from the deep waters of
   Western Australia is decribed as Ellatrivia detavorai n. sp.

   Sulawesi, Indonesia.

SO Visaya
VL 3
IS 1
PS 69-72

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The camaenid pulmonate Chloritis johannisi n. sp. is described from the
   island of Peleng, Sulawesi, Indonesia, by means of conchological
   characteristics. It can be distinguished from the sympatric congener
   Chloritis gruneri by the presence of periostracal hair and from the
   similar Chloritis talahensis by size, colour, hair density and whorl
   number.

DT Article
TI Systematic review and cladistic analysis of the Hernandariinae
   (Opiliones: Gonyleptidae).
AU DaSilva, Marcio Bernardino (1940@uol.com.br) 
   Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo
SO Zoologia
VL 27
IS 4
PS 577-642
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB The harvestmen subfamily Hernandariinae is reviewed and a new
   classification is proposed based on cladistic analysis using 67
   morphological characters. The subfamily is composed of six genera and 23
   species and occurs in south-southeastern Brazil, Paraguay, and
   northeastern Argentina. Fourteen new combinations are proposed:
   Hernandaria armatifrons (Roewer, 1917); H. una (Mello-Leitao, 1927);
   Acrogonyleptes granulatus (H. Snares, 1966); A. pectinifemur (Soares &
   Soares, 1947); Acanthogonyleptes alticola (Mello-Leitao 1922); A. editus
   (Roewer, 1943); A. fallax (Mello-Leitao, 1932); A. fulvigranulatus
   (Mello-Leitao, 1922); A. marmoratus (Mello-Leitao, 1940); A. pictus
   (Piza, 1942); A. singularis (Mello-Leitao 1935); A. soaresi
   (Mello-Leitao, 1944); A. variolosus (Mello-Leitao, 1944). Seven
   synonymies are proposed: Proweyhia Mello-Leitao, 1927 and Metaxundarava
   Mello-Leitao, 1927 = Hernandaria Sorensen, 1884; Apembolephaenus
   calcaratus Soares & Soares, 1945 = H. armatifrons (Roewer, 1917);
   Sphaerobunus Rower, 1917 and Paraproweyhia Soares & Soares, 1947 =
   Acrogonyleptes Roewer, 1917; Paraproweyhia curitibae Soares & Soares,
   1947 = Acrogonyleptes exochus (Mello-Leitao, 1931); and Melloleitaniana
   curitibae B. Soares, 1943 = Acrogonyleptes spinifrons Roewer, 1917.
   Three species are revalidated: Acrogonyleptes granulatus (H. Soares,
   1966), A. pectinifemur (Soares & Soares, 1947), and A. spinifrons
   Roewer, 1917. Seven new species are described: Hernandaria
   sundermannorum sp. nov. (Sao Paulo State, Brazil), Hernandaria
   anitagaribaldiae sp. nov. (Santa Catarina State, Brazil), Hernandaria
   zumbii sp. nov. (Santa Catarina State, Brazil), Hernandaria chicomendesi
   sp. nov. (Santa Catarina State, Brazil), Acrogonyleptes cheguevarai sp.
   nov. (Rio Grande do Sul State, Brazil), Pseudotrogulus pagu sp. nov.
   (Sao Paulo State, Brazil), Pseudotrogulus trotskyi sp. nov. (Parana
   State, Brazil).

DT Article
TI On the Neotropical spider genus Eurymorion (Araneae: Linyphiidae).
AU Lopes Rodrigues, Everton Nei (enlrodrigues@yahoo.com.br) 
   Ott, Ricardo
SO Zoologia
VL 27
IS 4
PS 649-659
PD August 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Neotropical genus of spider Eurymorion includes, until now, only two
   species: E. insigne (Millidge, 1991) and E. nobile (Millidge, 1991);
   both known only by males from the states of Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo
   (Southeastern Brazil), respectively. The genus is diagnosed mainly by
   the male palp with a small paracymbium and by the prolonged and medially
   constricted abdomen. In this paper we describe and illustrate three news
   species: E. triunfo sp. nov. based on male and female specimens from the
   states of Parana, Santa Catarina and Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil) and La
   Paz (Bolivia), male palp has a rounded lamella characteristica with less
   projected tip and less developed base of the frontal cheliceral
   spiniform process, females have long spermatic ducts following the
   course of the lateral borders of genital opening; E. murici sp. nov.
   based on a male and a female from the state of Alagoas (Brazil), male
   palp has a striated border lamella characteristica with less projected
   tip, subtegulum more than half the length of the cymbium, tegular duct
   forming a non sinuous curve and large frontal cheliceral spiniform
   process, female epigynum atrium with rounded lateral borders, less
   developed dorsal plate and separated spermathecae; and E. mourai sp.
   nov. based on a male from Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil), male palp with
   less prominent lamella characteristica distal end, embolic division with
   only one distal projection, frontal cheliceral spiniform process larger
   and with slightly bifurcated tip. In addition, new illustrations based
   on the type material of the E. insigne and E. nobile are provided and
   the female of E. nobile is described and illustrated for the first time.
C1 Lopes Rodrigues, Everton Nei; Univ Fed Rio Grande Sul, Inst Biociencias,
   Ave Bento Goncalves 9500,Bloco 4,Predio 43435, Porto Alegre, RS, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM enlrodrigues@yahoo.com.br
OI Rodrigues, Everton/0000-0002-9814-0954
SC Zoology
SN 1984-4670; 1984-4689
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Eurymorion [Bolivia /  / Distribution; systematics] [Brazil /  / ]. 
   Eurymorion mourai; Eurymorion murici [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Eurymorion triunfo [Bolivia /  / New species] [Brazil /  / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI A revision of the Appalachian millipede genus Brachoria Chamberlin, 1939
   (Polydesmida: Xystodesmidae: Apheloriini).
AU Marek, Paul E. (pmarek@email.arizona.edu) 
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 159
IS 4
PS 817-889
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB The apheloriine millipede genus Brachoria as presented here comprises 34
   species distributed throughout the south- eastern US Appalachian
   Mountains. Members of this genus are blind (like all millipedes in the
   order Polydesmida), large (4-6 cm in length), and display conspicuous
   aposematic coloration in yellow, red, orange, and violet. Many Brachoria
   species participate in mimicry rings with co-occurring Apheloriini, in
   particular with species in the genus Apheloria. Some areas contain five
   co-mimic species of Apheloriini and a high local density totalling 43
   individuals per 50 m2. Since the first revision in 1959, workers have
   suggested that many more species were awaiting discovery in the
   Cumberland Mountains. Here I present a taxonomic revision and describe
   ten new species: Brachoria badbranchensis, Brachoria blackmountainensis,
   Brachoria campcreekensis, Brachoria cumberlandmountainensis, Brachoria
   flammipes, Brachoria grapevinensis, Brachoria gun- termountainensis,
   Brachoria hendrixsoni, Brachoria sheari, and Brachoria virginia. Five of
   these new species occur in the Cumberland Mountain Thrust Block region
   and five occur elsewhere throughout the Appalachian Highlands in eastern
   Kentucky, north- eastern Alabama, southern West Virginia, south- western
   Virginia, and the Blue Ridge Mountains of Tennessee. A molecular
   phylogeny of Brachoria species is well supported at deeper divergences,
   corresponds closely with geography, and is used as a phylogenetic basis
   for the taxonomy presented here.
C1 Marek, Paul E.; Univ Arizona, Dept Entomol, Forbes Bldg, Tucson, AZ,
   USA, USA.
EM pmarek@email.arizona.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0024-4082

   Zoogeography; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA

   cumberlandmountainensis; Brachoria flammipes; Brachoria grapevinensis
   [Kentucky /  / New species].

   Brachoria guntermountainensis [Alabama /  / New species]. 
   Brachoria hendrixsoni [Tennessee /  / New species]. 
   Brachoria sheari [Kentucky /  / New species] [Virginia /  / ]. 
   Brachoria virginia [Virginia /  / New species].

   Brachoria hendrixsoni (Diplopoda): [Sp nov, Tennessee, P. 856].

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Tegastes (Copepoda: Harpacticoida:
   Tegastidae) from Hydrothermal Vents in the Okinawa Trough.
AU Back, Jinwook
   Huys, Rony
   Lee, Wonchoel (wlee@hanyang.ac.kr) 
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 27
IS 8
PS 678-688
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We describe a new species, Tegastes okinawaensis, from 583-711
   meter-deep hydrothermal vents in the Okinawa Trough, Japan. This species
   is clearly distinguishable from its congeners by four combined
   characters, namely 1) the last three abdominal somites are depressed
   inwardly towards the body, 2) there is sexual dimorphism in the number
   of setae of P3 and P4, 3) the male antennule is 9-segmented, with the
   7th segment formed by incomplete fusion of two segments, and 4) the
   caudal rami are small with a distorted quadrangular shape. Additionally,
   the species is easily distinguishable from its congeners by the distal
   endopodal segment of P4, which is armed with six setae - this character
   has never been reported in previous descriptions of congeners. This
   report is the first of a species in the genus Tegastes living at ocean
   depths of greater than 580 m in the northwestern Pacific.
C1 Lee, Wonchoel; Hanyang Univ, Dept Life Sci, Seoul, South Korea, South
   Korea.
EM wlee@hanyang.ac.kr
RI Lee, Wonchoel/L-9822-2018
OI Lee, Wonchoel/0000-0002-9873-1033
SC Marine &Freshwater Biology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0289-0003

   factors; Physical factors; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Tegastes [Hydrothermal vent /  / ] [Depth / Depth record / ] [North
   Pacific / Japan, Okinawa Trough / ]. 
   Tegastes okinawaensis [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Harpacticoida
OR Tegastes (Harpacticoida). 
   Tegastes okinawaensis (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 679].

DT Article
TI A New Genus of Endoparasitic Copepods (Cyclopoida: Enterognathidae),
   Forming a Gall in the Calyx of Deep-sea Crinoids.
AU Ohtsuka, Susumu (ohtsuka@hiroshima-u.ac.jp) 
   Kitazawa, Kota
   Boxshall, Geoffrey A.
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 27
IS 8
PS 689-696
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new genus and species of cyclopoid copepod belonging to the family
   Enterognathidae, Parenterognathus troglodytes, is described from a gall
   on the calyx of the deep-sea crinoid Glyptometra crassa (Clark, 1912)
   collected at depths of 775-787 m off Kumano-nada, middle Japan. The new
   genus can be distinguished from the three known genera of the family by
   body tagmosis and by the segmentation and armature of the appendages.
   This is the first record of this family from the Pacific Ocean. This
   family seems to be host-specific to relatively basal deuterostomes, such
   as echinoderms and hemichordates. The evolutionary transformation and
   history of the Enterognathidae are briefly discussed.
C1 Ohtsuka, Susumu; Hiroshima Univ, Takehara Marine Sci Stn, 5-8-1 Minato
   Machi, Hiroshima, Japan, Japan.
EM ohtsuka@hiroshima-u.ac.jp

   Geoffrey/0000-0001-8170-7734

SN 0289-0003

AN ZOOR14701002837
PM 20695786
DT Article
TI A Review of Roquettea, with Description of Three New Brazilian Species
   and Notes on Gryne (Opiliones, Cosmetidae, Discosomaticinae).
AU Ferreira, Claudio P. (cppires@gmail.com) 
   Kury, Adriano B.
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 27
IS 8
PS 697-708
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Roquettea Mello-Leitao, hitherto monotypic and known from
   Brazilian state of Para, is rediagnosed, the type species, Roquettea
   singularis is redescribed, including a report on two male morphs, being
   the second record of male polymorphism in Cosmetidae, the first in South
   America. Three new species are described from northern Brazil-Roquettea
   taurina n. sp. (which possesses a unique horned ocularium) and Roquettea
   jalapensis n. sp. (without notable scutal structures), both from the
   state of Tocantins, being the first record of the family Cosmetidae from
   Tocantins; and Roquettea scrotalis n. sp. (with a unique 2-balled dorsal
   tuberous complex) from Amapa state, being the first record of the
   subfamily Discosomaticinae from Amapa. Roquettea is compared to the
   closely related genus Gryne, both currently placed in Discosomaticinae,
   and also to Protus, the type genus of the subfamily. The unity of
   Discosomaticinae is discussed, and evidence for the monophyly of this
   subfamily is weak at best. Male genitalia are for the first time
   illustrated and described for genera Protus, Roquettea and Gryne, and
   SEM micrographs are used for the first time in descriptions of
   Cosmetidae.
C1 Ferreira, Claudio P.; Museu Nacl UFRJ Quinta da Boa Vista, Dept
   Invertebrados, Rio De Janeiro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM cppires@gmail.com
RI Kury, Adriano Brilhante/C-3202-2009
OI Kury, Adriano Brilhante/0000-0002-8334-6204
SC Zoology
SN 0289-0003

DT Article
TI Nomadolepis (Cyclophyllidea, Hymenolepididae), a new genus of cestodes
   from rodents.
AU Makarikov, A.A. (makarikov@mail.ru) 
   Gulyaev, V.D.
   Krivopalov, A.V.
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 89
IS 8
PS 948-955
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 5
AB The new genus, Nomadolepis gen. n., is described. The redescription of
   the type species, Nomadolepis merionis (Tokobajev et Erculov 1966) comb.
   n., from the grey hamster (Cricetulus migratorius Pall.) from the
   Tarbagatay Ridge (southeastern Kazakhstan)) and description of N.
   ellobii gen. n. from the mole vole (Ellobius talpinus Pall.) from
   southern Western Siberia are presented. Nomadolepis gen. n. is
   characterized by fraternoide rostellar hooks, right-side genital
   atriums, a copulative part of vagina, bilobate uterus, which does not
   surpass excretory canals, and numerous polar filaments of the
   embryophore. A differential diagnosis of Nomadolepis gen. n. is given.
C1 Makarikov, A.A.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Div, Novosibirsk, Russia,
   Russia.
EM makarikov@mail.ru

   parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   parasite species] [Russia /  / New platyhelminth parasite species]. 
   Rodentolepis ellobii [Mammalian hosts / Ellobius talpinus / New parasite
   species] [Russia /  / New species from mammalian host]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Platyhelminths; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae,
   Platyhelminthes, Cestoda

   Nomadolepis (Cestoda): [Gen nov, Of family Hymenolepididae, Type species
   Rodentolepis merionis Tokobejev & Erculov 1966, p. 953]. 
   Nomadolepis merionis - (Tokobejev & Erculov 1966) (Cestoda):
   [Redescription, P. 949; Comb nov, Transferred from Rodentolepis, p.
   948].

PT J
AN ZOOR14702016827
DT Article
TI New species of shore-flies of the genus Notiphila (Diptera, Ephydridae)
   from Thailand.
AU Krivosheina, M.G. (dipteramarina@rambler.ru) 
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 89
IS 8
PS 1012-1015
PD Aug 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB The new species of the shore-flies, Notiphila thaica sp. n., from
   Thailand is described. The species is characterized by yellow antennae,
   eye-to-cheek index 7: 1, yellow tibiae and tarsi of all legs and long
   directed posteriorly setae on abdominal segments III-IV. Generally, the
   species resembles Notiphila puncta de Meijere due to many brown stripes
   on its thorax, differing from it in the absence of velvety-black spots
   on frons, 2 strong facial setae and unicolour wings. The new species is
   close to N. phaea Hendel in the structure of genitalia, differing from
   it by striate coloration, larger body and apically widened surstyli. A
   key to oriental species of Notiphila is given.
C1 Krivosheina, M.G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Ecol & Evolut, Moscow, Russia,
   Russia.
EM dipteramarina@rambler.ru
RI Krivosheina, Marina/E-9420-2014
SC Zoology
SN 0044-5134
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Notiphila [Oriental region /  / Key to species]. 
   Notiphila thaica [Thailand /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Ephydridae
OR Notiphila - Fallen 1810 (Ephydridae): [Key to species, Oriental region,
   P. 1013]. 
   Notiphila thaica (Ephydridae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 1012].

TI NEW RECORDS OF TIGER BEETLES FROM NEW ZEALAND WITH TAXONOMIC AND
   NOMENCLATURAL NOTES ON THE GENUS NEOCICINDELA (Coleoptera,
   Cicindelidae).
AU Cassola, Fabio (fabiocassola@alice.it) 
   Moravec, Jiri
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 1-22
PD 31 luglio 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper deals with several new faunistic data and remarks on
   the taxonomy and nomenclature of the New Zealand endemic genus
   Neocicindela Rivalier, 1963, based on examination of type specimens of
   several taxa. N. novaseelandica (W. Horn, 1892) comb. nov. is restored
   as an independent species closely related to but well separated from N.
   helmsi (Sharp, 1886). Field photographs, as well as those of type
   specimens and some of their characters are given.

PT J
AN ZOOR14707051884
DT Article
TI A new species of Duvalius from Umbria, belonging to aew phylethic line
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
FT UN NUOVO DUVALIUS DELL'UMBRIA, APPARTENENTE A UNA NUOVA LINEA FILETICA
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Magrini, Paolo (duvalius@paolomagrini.it) 
   Degiovanni, Augusto
   Cirocchi, Fulvio
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 23-34
PD 31 luglio 2010
PY 2010
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 2
AB In this paper is described Duvalius irmoi n. sp., a new unpigmented and
   anoph- thalmic species from Umbria (Lo Sprofondo Cave, No 420 U/Pg,
   Monte Tezio), where it may prove to be more frequent in the MSS than in
   the large caves found in the area. It has a small copulatory piece, with
   a forked lamina shaped a gutter, topped by a large, uneven, quadrangular
   median phanerous. The shape unusual of the piece places this species at
   the head of a new group of species which we have named the "irmoi
   group". Its presence within the Etruscan Triangle (delimited by the
   rivers Arno, Tevere and Tyr- rhenian Coast, where this genus had
   previously been unknown) suggests that further research in the area
   could lead to the discovery of other new taxa. The new group is mid- way
   between the northern "vallombrosus group" (Tuscany-Romagna) and the
   southern "straneoi group" (Umbria-Marche-Latium-Abruzzi). The copulatory
   piece resembles that of some Duvalius of the "vallombrosus group", but
   lacks the prominent rounded packet of pins of this latter (see text
   illustrations). The packet of pins is replaced by the large, uneven,
   quadrangular median phanerous, similar to that of some species in the
   "straneoi group".
C1 Magrini, Paolo; Via Gianfilippo Braccini 7, Florence, Italy, Italy.
EM duvalius@paolomagrini.it
SC Zoology
SN 0429-288X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Duvalius irmoi [Italy /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Duvalius irmoi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 24].

OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

TI CATALOGUE OF THE STAPHYLINIDAE OF CYPRUS AND ASIA MINOR (Coleoptera).
AU Bordoni, Arnaldo (arnaldo.bordoni@libero.it) 
SO Fragmenta Entomologica
VL 42
IS 1
PS 35-348
PD 31 luglio 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The catalogue includes all the species described and/or referred to
   Cyprus and Asia Minor until 2007 inclusive. The bibliography on the
   species description to that of 20012002 and the geonemical citations is
   generally available in Herman (2001) and Smetana (2002); that of the
   species described or mentioned in contributions appeared after 2002 can
   be found in the bibliography at the hend of this catalogue. Described
   species of Cyprus and/or Asia minor are accompanied by the following
   informations: type locality or list of the localitys mentioned in the
   description, institutions or collections where is preserved the type,
   whether is male or female or if you do not know the sex; if it has been
   designed the lectotype and the author of the designation, the
   distribution. Some synonymies are proposed which will be discussed
   elsewhere, and some general remarks on the genus Geostiba Thomson.

TI A new genus and species of micropterous Oriental Aradidae (Hemiptera,
   Heteroptera, Aradidae).
AU Heiss, Ernst (aradus@aon.at) 
SO Linzer Biologische Beitraege
VL 42
IS 1
PS 81-87
PD 30 Juli 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB From Sikkim, Northern India, a new micropterous Mezirinae genus,
   Sikkimocoris nov. gen. is described to accommodate the type species S
   rumtek nov. sp. A second species of the so far monotypic genus
   Pahangiessa HEISS 1993, P. schuhui nov. sp. is described from Malaysia
   and an additional record for P. bulboscutellata is given. Structural
   details are illustrated and photographs are given for all species.
